Line 123: Line 123:
=== 28 January â Friday of Anger ===
=== 28 January â Friday of Anger ===
  +
[[File:Qasr_al_Nil_Jan29.jpg |thumb|Protesters clashing with riot police on the [[Qasr al-Nil Bridge]] on 29 January.]]
Thousands filled the streets across Egypt on Friday 28 January, dubbed âthe Friday of Angerâ.<ref name="Friday of Anger">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/be97d4a8-2b0b-11e0-a65f-00144feab49a.html#axzz1CMDTT7Ao|title=Pent-up anger bursts on to Cairo streets|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=28 January 2011|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref><ref>http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/01/awaiting-the-friday-of-anger.html</ref> Shortly before 1:00 local time, hours ahead of the expected massive anti-government protests, the Egyptian government shut down internet service, although some people were still able to communicate using alternative means.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh protests erupt in Egypt - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arabist.net/blog/2011/1/28/urgent-egypt-has-shut-off-the-internet.html |title=URGENT: Egypt has shut off the internet |publisher=Arabist |last=El Amrani |first=Issandr |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref> Text messaging and mobile phone services also appeared to be blocked.<ref>{{cite web|author=By the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1&iref=BN1 |title=Violent clashes erupt during protests in Egypt |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> All mobile operators in Egypt have been instructed to suspend services in selected areas. Under Egyptian legislation the authorities have the right to issue such an order and the operators are obliged to comply with it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/press.html |title=Press |publisher=Vodafone |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref>
Thousands filled the streets across Egypt on Friday 28 January, dubbed âthe Friday of Angerâ.<ref name="Friday of Anger">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/be97d4a8-2b0b-11e0-a65f-00144feab49a.html#axzz1CMDTT7Ao|title=Pent-up anger bursts on to Cairo streets|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=28 January 2011|publisher=Financial Times}}</ref><ref>http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/01/awaiting-the-friday-of-anger.html</ref> Shortly before 1:00 local time, hours ahead of the expected massive anti-government protests, the Egyptian government shut down internet service, although some people were still able to communicate using alternative means.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh protests erupt in Egypt - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.arabist.net/blog/2011/1/28/urgent-egypt-has-shut-off-the-internet.html |title=URGENT: Egypt has shut off the internet |publisher=Arabist |last=El Amrani |first=Issandr |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-01-18}}</ref> Text messaging and mobile phone services also appeared to be blocked.<ref>{{cite web|author=By the CNN Wire Staff |url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1&iref=BN1 |title=Violent clashes erupt during protests in Egypt |publisher=CNN.com |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> All mobile operators in Egypt have been instructed to suspend services in selected areas. Under Egyptian legislation the authorities have the right to issue such an order and the operators are obliged to comply with it.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/press.html |title=Press |publisher=Vodafone |date= |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref>
